lesson.title: Cloud Performance and Optimization
lesson.summary: Performance and cloud resources are closely related to costs and resource allocation.  In this lesson, we will explore ways to utilize AWS services to optimize performance.

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 01 Intro To Performance And Scalability
Lesson Learning objectives and outline
atoms.text:
### Key Points
- Moving your applications to the cloud doesn’t guarantee that your performance issues will automatically be resolved, especially if you lift and shift.

- AWS provides services that will assist you in improving your application performance, but optimization is the key. 

In this lesson we'll explore the following topics related to performance in the cloud:   
- Scaling  
- Storage  
- Archive  
- Database  
- Message Queues  
- Networking

atoms.title: Infrastructure Performance in the Cloud heading
atoms.text: ## Infrastructure Performance in the Cloud

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 02 Infrastructure Performance In The Cloud
Glossary
atoms.text:
###  New Terms  
| Term | Definition |
|:----------------------|:----| 
| Burstable Performance Instances 	| T3, T3a, and T2 instances, are designed to provide a baseline level of CPU performance with the ability to burst to a higher level when required by your workload 	|
| Elasticity 	| The ability to grow or shrink infrastructure resources dynamically as needed to automatically adapt to workload changes, maximizing the use of resources and resulting in savings in infrastructure costs 	|
| GPU  (Graphics Processing Unit)  |A programmable chip used to manage and boost the performance of video and graphics. GPU renders images, animations, and video for the computer's screen 	|
| Instance Family 	| Six distinct classifications of EC2 instance optimized for different types of applications 	|
| Lift and  Shift  | The process of moving your application from an on-premises environment to the cloud without making any major changes to the code  | 
| Optimized Instances 	| Instance types optimized to fit different use cases. Instance types comprise varying combinations of CPU, memory, storage, GPU, and networking capacity and give you the flexibility to choose the appropriate mix of resources for your applications 	|
| Workload 	| A collection of resources and code that delivers business value, such as a customer-facing application or a backend process 	|

atoms.title: Performance  in the Cloud Lesson Recap
atoms.text:
### Optimization Game Plan   
1. Run performance tests
2. Capture and analyze metrics
3. Select the optimal instance  
4. Monitor for outliers to make sure the optimal instance continues to be optimal

### Best Practices for Optimizing for Performance  

- Design your workload infrastructure with performance in mind from the start
- Whenever possible, design your workload or application to be cloud native
- Utilize compute elasticity to manage performance peaks and valleys 
- Optimize until your performance meets benchmarks



#### Have the Optimized Instances Changed?

AWS is constantly changing. Check to see the latest optimized instance types here: [Amazon EC2 Instance Types](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/)

question.prompt: Select the EC2 Instance Family Optimization Options available in AWS

atoms.title: How do you know header
atoms.text: ## How Do You Know When Your App Isn't Performing?

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 03 How Do You Know Your App Isn'T Performing-

question.prompt: Select the Performance factors affecting workloads in the cloud that you probably cannot control

atoms.title: Recap
atoms.text:
### Questions to Ask When You Have A Performance Issue


- How did this workload get into our environment?
- Did you lift and shift or did you design the application to be cloud native from the start?
- Did you accidentally over-optimize your compute and not leave any room for unexpected performance peaks or periods of high activity?

### What AWS Services Can Do When Problems Are Detected

- Spin up instances (scale out)
- Terminate instances
- Increase memory
- Optimize network routes  
- Failover to a backup  


Even though your application or workload may not be cloud native, you still have an incredible variety of options for improving your performance and avoiding outages and incidents

atoms.title: Scaling Elasticity and Bursting header
atoms.text: ## Scaling, Elasticity, and Bursting

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 04 Scaling, Elasticity, And Bursting
Scaling, Elasticity etc recap
atoms.text:
### Scaling, Elasticity, and Bursting

The three primary functions built in to AWS to address increases in compute demand are bursting, elasticity and scaling 

- Burstable instances provide your application a baseline level of CPU performance with the ability to burst to a higher level when required by your workload. These instances are great for workloads like fast interactive applications, moderately sized databases, and lower lifecycles like Development and test.. AWS burstable instances are T2 and T3 instance types.

- Elasticity is the ability to acquire resources as you need them, and elasticity is ALSO releasing resources when you no longer need them. A service isn’t elastic unless it releases resources it no longer needs, another major cloud differentiator. 

- AWS Auto Scaling monitors your applications based on criteria you specify and automatically adjusts capacity to maintain availability and performance. Autoscaling is an example of scaling up when you add servers as you need them, and scaling down when you wind down and terminating servers you no longer need

question.prompt: The ability to acquire and release resources a needed is called

atoms.title: High Performing Instances heading
atoms.text: ## AWS Performance Optimized Instances

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 05 High Performing AWS Instances
Glossary
atoms.text:
###  New Terms 

 
| Term | Definition |
|:----------------------|:----| 
| Accelerated Computing Instance Families 	| Use hardware accelerators, or co-processors, to perform some functions, such as floating point number calculations, graphics processing, or data pattern matching, more efficiently than is possible in software running on CPUs 	|
| Auto Scaling Group 	|AWS EC2 instances that are treated as a logical grouping for the purposes of automatic scaling and management 	|
| Launch Configuration | An instance configuration template that an Auto Scaling group uses to launch EC2 instances	|
| Placement Groups 	| Influence the placement of a group of interdependent instances to meet the needs of your workload 	|
| Predictive Scaling 	| A feature of AWS Auto Scaling uses machine learning to schedule the right number of EC2 instances in anticipation of approaching traffic changes. Predictive Scaling predicts future traffic, including regularly-occurring spikes, and provisions the right number of EC2 instances in advance 	|
| Target Utilization 	| The threshold we define at how much utilization (in %) we want auto scaling to take place |

atoms.title: High Performing EC2 Instance Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points  

- Performance data is the key to choosing the proper instance family choice for your workload
- AWS optimized instances can provide higher throughput for intensive workloads  
- Optimized instance sizes and generations change frequently to improve performance and lower cost  
- Follow the [AWS Blog](https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/) to stay on top of changes

question.prompt: Select the best accelerated computing instances for an application that requires 3D game streaming.  You may want to check the AWS documentation for [EC2 Instance Types](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/).
Which term below describes the capability of servers to scale in and scale out?

atoms.title: High Performance Computing header
atoms.text: ## High Performing Infrastructure vs. High Performance Computing

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 06 High Performance Computing
Quantum Scale
atoms.caption:
A SGI Altix supercomputer with 23,000 processors at the CINES facility in France
Penalva / CC BY-SA
atoms.alt: A SGI Altix supercomputer with 23,000 processors at the CINES facility in France

question.title: Reflect
question.text: What do you think about going viral in the cloud? Is it really worth the money? It depends on what it's worth to you. Please share your thoughts.

answer.text:
Going viral in the cloud has costs associated with the increased traffic to your web pages. The costs may or may not be significant. Configuring your site to autoscale, even with elasticity, will add to your bottom line at the end of the month. Is it worth it? Let's say you are a small vendor with a small handmade inventory of low priced products. It probably isn’t worth the extra expense. The first few visitors will buy all your inventory, the latecomers will crash your site, and you will go off to sew your quilts or distill your perfume while the internet recovers and looks for the next big thing. 

However, if you would welcome the attention and demand, you have plenty of valuable resources to share, and you will recoup the value in the additional expense, it is absolutely worth it to configure your site to autoscale when traffic increases. An example would be a person with deep knowledge on an obscure topic that few people know about. All of a sudden, the obscure topic starts trending and leads people directly to your site where you have several PDFs on the topic for sale and available for download! You will make up in valuable exposure what you could probably never buy on your own- publicity! 

Another example would be a silly photo posted on your personal blog being linked by a Twitter account with millions of followers. People are going to click, laugh, and move on while AWS spins up servers and your costs rise. If you want to provide the world with a few hundred dollars worth of humor, you should do it! You might end up with a write up in Buzzfeed or an invite to The Ellen Show!

- [High Performance Computing in AWS](https://aws.amazon.com/hpc/)  
- [Placement Groups](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/placement-groups.html)

atoms.title: Storage Volumes heading
atoms.text: ## Storage Volumes and Latency

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 07 Storage Volumes And Latency - Improve Performance
Glossary
atoms.text:
### New Terms  


| Term 	| Definition |
|---------	|-----------|
| Availability 	| A storage volume’s ability to deliver data upon request 	|
| Data Durability 	| Refers to long-term data protection, so the stored data does not suffer from degradation or some other corruption. Durability is focused on redundancy, , sodata is never lost or compromised 	|
| Elastic Block Store 	| High performance block storage service designed for use with Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) for both throughput and transaction intensive workloads 	|
| Elastic File System 	| Fully managed elastic NFS file system for use with AWS Cloud services and on-premises resources. It is built to scale on demand to petabytes without disrupting applications, growing and shrinking automatically 	|
| IOPS 	| Input/output operations per second (IOPS, pronounced eye-ops) is an input/output performance measurement used to benchmark computer storage devices like hard disk drives (HDD), solid state drives (SSD) 	|
| Performance 	| Refers to the number of IOPS or the amount of throughput (measured in megabytes per second) that the storage volume can deliver 	|
| Throughput 	| Measurement of  data that can be transferred from one location to another in a given amount of time used to measure the performance of hard drives and RAM as well as Internet and network connections 	|
| Transient or Ephemeral Data 	| Data created within an application session, and at the end of the session, it is discarded or reset back to its default and not stored 	|

atoms.title: Storage Volumes lesson recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points  

Amazon has three storage categories for object, block, and file storage

- **Simple Storage Service (S3)** 
  -  Highly durable object storage optimized for media files  
  -  Guarantees 99.999999999% availability
- **Elastic Block Store (EBS)**  
  -  EC2 attached block storage comprised of workload specific hard drives  
  -  Must be provisioned in advance, so you may end up paying for storage you are not using
- **Elastic File System( EFS)** 
 -  Elastic file storage for named files that require a file structure, such as big data workloads and web sites. 
  - Truly elastic and it will expand and contract as you use it. 

In addition, **AWS Instance Store** is considered ephemeral data attached to an EC2 instance that is deleted when the instance is terminated.



### Best Practices for Optimized Object Storage  
- Spread connection requests to maximize the accessible bandwidth
- Access in the same AWS Region when possible to reduce latency and data transfer costs
- Use AWS S3 Transfer Acceleration for fast and secure data transfer over long distances  
- Use Instance Store for ephemeral storage  
-  **Always delete unused storage volumes and obsolete snapshots!!!**

question.prompt: Which of the characteristics below are TRUE of AWS Elastic File System?

answers.text: Can be shared by thousands of instances
Can only be used on Windows based EC2 instances
Files can be moved to EFS IA if they aren’t accessed in a certain period of time
Grows and shrinks elastically as files are added and removed

question.prompt: AWS S3 Glacier is object storage for what specific data tier?

atoms.title: EBS and EFS Performance Heading
atoms.text: ## EBS and EFS Performance

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 08 EBS And EFS Performance
EFS vs EBS Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points 

Amazon EBS or Elastic Block Storage is provisioned capacity and performance  

- Pay for the EBS storage even if it is unattached or has very low read/write activity.One of the - Need to audit your environment to detect and delete obsolete EBS volumes and adjust the size of your provisioned storage to match your actual use.
- EBS volumes attached to EBS optimized instances can be accessed using dedicated networks for better throughput 
- Non-EBS optimized instances share the network with all the rest of the local traffic  


Amazon EFS or Elastic File Storage has optimization built into the service
-  Distributed to make it highly available, durable, and scalable.
-  Can be mounted on up to thousands of Amazon EC2 instances concurrently
-  Supports encryption in transit and encryption at rest with a minimal effect on I/O latency and throughput

question.prompt: You are developing an application that requires 4 EC2 Instance to access the same locally attached file system. Which AWS storage option would be ideal for mounting to multiple servers at the same time?

atoms.title: EFS Demo header
atoms.text: ## Getting Started with EFS

atoms.title: EFS Demo recap
atoms.text:
## Key Points

- Amazon Elastic File System is a scalable NFS file system that grows and shrinks elastically as you add and remove files. There is no need to provision EFS storage, and you only pay for what you use.

- AWS EFS files can be automatically moved to a lower infrequently accessed tier (EFS-IA) after they haven’t been accessed for a certain period of time. 

- EFS supports any number of concurrent EC2 instance connections. Thousands of connections is not uncommon.

atoms.title: EBS Screencast Demo Header
atoms.text: ## Getting Started with EBS

atoms.title: CAND C2 Getting Started With EBS 1
EBS page with Block Storage List
atoms.caption: EBS Options: SSDs vs HDDs

atoms.title: EBS Slides recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points 

- EBS volumes are highly durable block storage hard drives that can either be created independently on the EBS management page or created with a new EC2 instance

- EBS volumes can be attached to and detached from instances and can be used just like any other hard drive- you can run databases, create file systems, and move them between instances
- EBS volumes are provisioned storage, so costs are incurred whether it is attached to an EC2 instance or not. Be mindful of idle EBS volumes and make sure they are necessary before you maintain unused volumes for long periods of time. 

- EBS snapshots are point-in-time backups of EBS volumes saved to S3 and serve as a lower cost alternative to maintaining idle EBS volumes

- AWS EBS provides SSD or HDD volumes. SSD are for low latency/high performance applications like databases and HDD are for high throughput applications like big data workloads and infrequently accessed files in cold storage.

- Costs with EBS HDD are considerably lower than EBS SSD

question.prompt: How do you get an EBS volume that is attached to an EC2 instance in one AZ (Availability Zone), moved over to an instance in another AZ?

answers.text: Detach the volume in the first AZ and reattach it to an instance in the new AZ
Create a snapshot of the EBS volume and create a new EBS volume from the snapshot in the other AZ
Create an new volume in the second AZ with the same volume ID and copy/paste the data to the new volume
Set up a share on the EBS volume so both EC2 instances can attach to it and read/write from it

atoms.title: EBS EFS demo heading
atoms.text: ## EBS Volumes on AWS

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 07.1 Resizing And EBS Volume
Resizing Steps
atoms.text:
### Steps to Resize EBS
1. [Launch an EC2 Instance](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EC2_GetStarted.html#ec2-launch-instance)  
2. Verify your EC2 instance is running on the EC2 dashboard
3.  Navigate to the Volumes link in the left menu under Elastic Block Store
4. On the Actions menu, select Modify Volume
5. Change the volume size and save

Note that we will need to take additional steps for the operating system to recognize the additional disk space. In order to do that, we will need to login to the server and expand the partition. [Extending a Linux File System after Extending a Volume](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/recognize-expanded-volume-linux.html#extend-linux-volume-partition)

atoms.title: Demo Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points  
- Before extending a file system that contains data, it is a best practice to create a snapshot of the volume in case you need to roll back your changes. We had an empty volume, so we didn’t have a need to take a snapshot today 

- We no longer need to stop the EC2 instance and detach the EBS volume to resize it. EBS volumes can be resized while running, even if the volume is the root volume of a running instance.

- After you increase the size of an EBS volume, you must use file system–specific commands to extend the file system to the larger size

 -  The volume must be formatted for the operating system it is attached to and mounted prior to use. 
-   New volumes must also have a file system installed prior to use. 
Read more here: 
- [Making an Amazon EBS Volume Available for Use on Linux](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-using-volumes.html)
- [Making an Amazon EBS Volume Available for Use on Windows](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/ebs-using-volumes.html)

question.prompt: Which EBS drive option would you select for a fast, high performance, and  mission critical application
Your application has a need for EBS storage for an EC2 instance that will store infrequently accessed data. What would be the best choice for this scenario?

atoms.title: Exercise Intro
atoms.text:
## Create an EBS Snapshot

An EBS Snapshot is a point-in-time copy of an EBS volume. EBS snapshots are copied to AWS S3 and stored with all of the data needed to restore the volume for use if it becomes necessary.

atoms.title: Create an EBS Snapshot
tasks: Create an EC2 instance with an 8GB general purpose SSD
Stop the running instance and make a note of the attached EBS volume identifier
Detach the EBS volume on the EBS management page
Create a snapshot of the detached 8GB EBS volume
View the snapshot on the Snapshots page
Delete the snapshot and  EBS Volume, terminate the instance, and log out of the AWS console
atoms.positive_feedback: Good Job!  I will walk you through the exercise in the next video.
atoms.description: Please follow the steps below to create an EBS Snapshot

atoms.title: Resizing Exercise Solution heading
atoms.text: ## My Solution

atoms.title: Solution Discussion
atoms.text:
## Key Points

- EBS snapshots are incremental copies of data, meaning only new/different blocks of data that have changed since the last snapshot are captured in the next snapshot.

- EBS Snapshots are stored in S3, but not in a user visible bucket. The bucket can be accessed via the EC2 CLI commands
- Snapshots can be used to create new volumes, create larger volumes, and create volumes in different availability zones

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Reading  

You can learn more about creating and managing EBS snapshots by following the links below:

- [Amazon EBS Snapshots](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EBSSnapshots.html)  
- [EBS Snapshots Explained](https://blog.skeddly.com/2017/03/ebs-snapshots-explained.html)

atoms.title: Glacier Archive Performance heading
atoms.text: ## Archive Performance

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 10 Glacier Archive Performance
Glossary
atoms.text:
### New Terms  


| Term    | Definition    | 
|----------------------|------------------------------| 
| S3 Glacier    | Storage service optimized for infrequently used, or "cold data." Glacier is a low-cost storage service that provides durable storage with security features for data archiving and backup | 
| S3 IA     | S3 storage class for data that is accessed less frequently, but requires rapid access when needed.           | 
| Expedited Retrieval  | Faster access to your data when you need to have almost immediate access to your information within 1-5 minutes. This retrieval type can be used for archives up to 250MB.      | 
| Retrieval Job        | An asynchronous operation in which you first initiate a job, and then download the output after the job completes    | 
| Provisioned Capacity |  Paying up front to ensure that S3 expedited retrieval capacity is available when you need it     |

atoms.title: Archive Options Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points
- AWS S3 Glacier provides S3 quality durable storage with delayed retrieval times in exchange for lower costs. Standard retrieval times can take 3-5 hours   
- AWS S3 IA is Amazon’s middle archive tier offering standard S3 object retrieval speeds for a lower cost. Objects in this storage tier are seldom retrieved, but can be brought back immediately

- Expedited Retrieval is a service to retrieve files from Glacier archive in minutes instead of hours.  It can be purchased on demand or provisioned in advance to ensure availability.

question.prompt: A user needs to use the expedited retrieval service to obtain a large set of objects from S3 Glacier during a period of very high demand, and they are unable to use the service. What Expedited Retrieval feature would have been useful in this situation?
Which S3 Storage Models offer immediate file retrieval?

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
###  Additional Reading   

The links below will take you to additional information about AWS storage options and how it can be managed for optimal costs and performance

- [S3 Storage Classes](https://aws.amazon.com/s3/storage-classes/)  
- [S3 Glacier](https://aws.amazon.com/glacier/)  
- [Amazon S3 Pricing](https://aws.amazon.com/s3/pricing/)   
- [S3 Glacier Provisioned Capacity](https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/glacier-provisioned-capacity/)

atoms.title: Creating an RDS database Heading
atoms.text: ##  Creating an RDS Database

atoms.title: Steps to Create an RDS Database
atoms.text:
### Steps to Create an Aurora RDS Database Cluster

1. Login to the AWS Management console
2. Search for RDS or browse to RDS in the Services console under Databases
3. On the AWS RDS Management console, select Create Database
4. Select Amazon Aurora (mySQL compatibility) as your RDS Database 
5. Name your DB cluster
6. Configure your DB engine, instance class and storage
7. Select admin password option
8. Specify optional cluster settings
9. Create Database
Read more here: [Creating an Amazon Aurora DB Cluster](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/AuroraUserGuide/Aurora.CreateInstance.html)

atoms.title: Read Replica header
atoms.text: ## Improving Performance with Read Replicas

atoms.title: Read Replica new terms
atoms.text:
### New Term  


| Term | Definition ||-------- | -------------|
| Read Replica | A copy of the master db that reflects changes to the master instance in almost real time.|

atoms.title: Read Replica recap
atoms.text:
### Read Replica  

- Read-only connections reduce read-traffic to the source database
- Allows source database to carry out other operations
- Good for business intelligence and financial engines
- Can be promoted in disaster recovery

### Steps to Create a Read Replica

1.  Login to the AWS Management Console
2. Browse to the RDS Management page
3. Select ‘Databases’ in the navigation menu
4. Select the radio button next to the database cluster where you want to create the reader
5. Under the ‘Actions’ menu, select Add Reader
6. On the Add Reader page, configure reader options
7. Create Reader
Read more here: [Adding Aurora Replicas to a DB Cluster](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/AuroraUserGuide/aurora-replicas-adding.html)

concepts.title: Exercise: Create an RDS with Read Replica

atoms.title: Exercise Intro
atoms.text: ## Create an RDS with Read Replica

atoms.title: Create an RDS with Read Replica
tasks: Login to the AWS Management Console and browse to the RDS service
Create an AWS Aurora Database (MySQL Compatible)
When the database is created, create a read replica in a different AZ
When you are finished with the exercise, delete the read replica and the Aurora database
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice Job!  See my solution in the next video.
atoms.description: Please follow the steps below to create an AWS RDS Aurora Database with a Read Replica

concepts.title: Solution: Create an RDS with Read Replica

atoms.title: RDS Solution Heading
atoms.text: ## My Solution

atoms.title: RDS With Read Replica Exercise Solution
Solution Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points 

- Read replicas contain the same data as the master database without the write capability of a master database. 

- Replicas are attached to the same storage as the master database, but they only support reading from the storage. Their primary purpose is to offload read activity so the master database has the resources to carry out read/writes and updates

- Replicas distributed across multiple AZs provide higher availability

- Replicas can be promoted to master database if, for some reason, the original master database becomes unavailable

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Reading  

Thank you for completing the RDS Read Replica exercise. Please follow the links below to learn more about AWS RDS and RDS Read Replicas. 

- [Creating an Amazon RDS DB Instance](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/UserGuide/USER_CreateDBInstance.html)  
- [Amazon RDS Read Replicas](https://aws.amazon.com/rds/features/read-replicas/) 
- [Working with Read Replicas](
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/UserGuide/USER_ReadRepl.html)

atoms.title: CF and Edge heading
atoms.text: ## Caching and Acceleration Concepts

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 12 Caching And Acceleration Concepts
Glossary
atoms.text:
### New Terms   


| Term 	| Definition 	|
|------------- |---------------------	|
| Content Delivery Network 	| A series of distributed servers that deliver content to users based on location 	|
| CloudFront 	| Uses a global network of 216 Points of Presence To deliver content to end users with lower latency 	|
| Edge Cache 	| Servers used to store content closer to end users 	|
| Edge Location 	| Where end users access services provided by AWS 	|
| Points of Presence 	| Made up of Edge locations and regional edge caches 	|

atoms.title: Caching Concepts Recap
atoms.text:
###  Key Points  

- Content Delivery Networks are systems of distributed proxy servers and Data Centers that deliver content based on the fastest route to the user's location

- CloudFront is Amazon’s CDN delivering content via a network of AWS data centers called Edge locations.

- Edge locations are located in most major cities around the world to deliver AWS content to users with reduced latency

- CloudFront uses the existing Amazon network to avoid exposure to the slower public internet routes and deliver content faster via AWS Edge locations.

- Content stays in the edge location for 24 hours unless an expiration time has been configured previously

question.prompt: Your company uses cloud front to distribute video content worldwide. How could you improve the performance of the application?

answers.text: Increase the cache expiration time for the videos
Install the Application in more Regions

question.prompt: Your application serves content from an S3 Standard Bucket in US-East-1. Some users in other countries have been complaining about slow response times. How can you easily fix this problem?

answers.text: Place the S3 bucket behind a CloudFront Distribution
Replicate your S3 bucket in regions closer to your users

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Reading    

Content Delivery Networks like AWS CloudFront are at the forefront of low-latency computing for improved application performance and user satisfaction. You can learn more about CloudFront and AWS Edge Locations, and how they contribute to high performing global applications by following the links below.

- [What is Amazon CloudFront](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/Introduction.html)  
- [CloudFront Key Features](https://aws.amazon.com/cloudfront/features/)  
- [Amazon CloudFront- The Ultimate Guide](https://serverless.com/amazon-cloudfront/)  
- [Creating an AWS CloudFront Distribution With S3 Origin](https://medium.com/tensult/creating-aws-cloudfront-distribution-with-s3-origin-ee47b8122727)

atoms.title: DB Acceleration Heading
atoms.text: ## Use a Data Driven Approach to Choose Database Type

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 13 DB Performance Accel
Glossary
atoms.text:
### New Terms  

| Term 	| Definition 	|
|----------- |------	|
| AWS DynamoDB | A key-value and document database that delivers single-digit millisecond performance at any scale. It's a fully managed, multiregion, multimaster, durable database with built-in security, backup and restore, and in-memory caching for internet-scale applications |
| AWS RDS | A web service that makes it easier to set up, operate, and scale a relational database in the cloud 	|
| Non-Relational Database 	| A database that does not use the tabular schema of rows and columns found in most traditional database systems. Instead, non-relational databases use a storage model that is optimized for the specific requirements of the type of data being stored |
| Relational Database | A set of formally described tables from which data can be accessed or reassembled in many different ways without having to reorganize the database tables |

atoms.title: RDS Features Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points  

- It’s important to take a data driven approach to choosing the right database solution for your application  

- In the AWS cloud, you don’t have to remain loyal to the same database you used on premises, especially if your application could benefit from a different mode. 

- With AWS RDS, you have the flexibility of selection the best database for your workload as opposed to being limited by the one database culture of on premises IT management

- AWS RDS is a managed service, meaning there is no access to the underlying hardware. Amazon manages the compute, memory, network and hardware related tasks.

- RDS optimizes most database tasks automatically and through periodic upgrades.

question.prompt: How would you best scale the AWS RDS database for an application that has heavy read pressure and very little write activity?

answers.text: Increase the size of the DB EBS instance storage
Create read replica(s) to handle the database reads
Update the database to the latest version

atoms.title: RDS Performance heading
atoms.text: ##  RDS Performance

atoms.title: New Terms
atoms.text:
### New Terms

| Term 	| Definition 	|
|------------- |---------------------	|
|RDS Instance Class            |  the CPU and memory capacity of an RDS instance; selected based on database performance requirements  |  
| Read Replica                      |  a copy of the master database that updates in near real-time to support read and analytics requests and relieve pressure and traffic on the master  |  
| Database I/O                       |  short for input/output, it refers to data transfer to or from a disk, and to or from memory  |  
| RDS Performance Insights  |  a database performance and monitoring dashboard that provides actionable insights in a format that is easy to interpret and understand  |

question.prompt: What is the optimal EBS option for a high performing database?
Read Replicas are copies of the master database that can be used for database reads and analytics processes like running reports. What is another feature of read replicas? Select two

answers.text: It can share write responsibility with the master database
It can be promoted to master if the master database becomes unavailable
It can replicate multiple master databases
It can reside in a different region than the master database

atoms.title: Message Queue heading
atoms.text: ## Use a Message Queue for Buffering

atoms.title: Glossary
atoms.text:
### New Terms  


| Term 	| Definition |
|------------ | -------|
| Consumer | Receives messages to an SQS queue |
| Decoupling | Refers to components remaining autonomous and unaware of each other as they complete their work for some greater output |
| FIFO 	| Queues designed to ensure that the order in which messages are sent and received is strictly preserved and that each message is processed exactly once- First In, First Out |
| Producer | Sends messages to an SQS queue |
| SQS 	| A fully managed message queuing service that enables you to decouple and scale microservices, distributed systems, and serverless applications |

atoms.title: Message Queues Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points

- An Amazon SQS queue is a reliable, scalable, and fully managed repository for messages that are awaiting processing

- Amazon SQS leverages the AWS cloud to dynamically scale based on demand. SQS scales elastically with your application so you don’t have to worry about capacity planning and pre-provisioning.

- SQS FIFO queues are designed to guarantee that messages are processed exactly once, in the exact order that they are sent

- For resiliency, the queue should use durable storage.

question.prompt: What SQS configuration should you use if you need to process messages in order?
What types of messages can an SQS queue ingest?

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Reading  

Please follow the links below to learn more about AWS SQS  

- [AWS SQS FAQs](https://aws.amazon.com/sqs/faqs/)  
- [AWS SQS Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/welcome.html)  
- [AWS SQS Ultimate Guide](https://serverless.com/amazon-sqs/)  
- [AWS SQS Tutorials](https://serverless.com/amazon-sqs/)

atoms.title: Network Optimization Heading
atoms.text: ##  Network Optimization

atoms.title: Glossary
atoms.text:
### New Terms  


| Term 	| Definition |
|-----|---------|
| AWS Direct Connect | A cloud service solution that makes it easy to establish a dedicated network connection from your premises to AWS |
| AWS Global Accelerator | Service that improves the availability and performance of your applications with local or global users. It provides static IP addresses that act as a fixed entry point to your application endpoints |
| AWS VPC Endpoints | Used to privately connect your VPC to other AWS services and endpoint services |
| Latency | Generally refers to a transport or transfer delay 	|
| Latency Routing | Configuration where DNS requests are routed from the AWS region that provides the lowest latency |
| Route 53 | A highly available and scalable cloud Domain Name System (DNS) web service |
| VPC 	| A logically isolated section of the AWS Cloud where you can launch AWS resources in a virtual network you define |

atoms.title: Network Perf Optimization Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points  

- Networking is essential to AWS - without the network, there is no cloud.

- AWS meets  the challenge of the unpredictability of the public internet and ISPs by providing services like VPC endpoints, S3 Content Acceleration, and CloudFront that use the AWS network backbone to improve network performance.

- Over the years, AWS has built out infrastructure and services to improve their own internal network performance to mitigate and reduce network challenges that may be out of their control

### AWS Load Balancers

- **Application Load Balancers** 
  - Best suited for load balancing of web traffic
  - Assigns load based on the performance attributes of your running code and not necessarily the traffic or load on your server
  - Supports a round-robin load balancing algorithm

- **Network Load Balancers**
  - Best for balancing TCP and UDP traffic
  - Can route traffic based on IP data (ideal for whitelisting applications)
  - Can handle millions of requests per second while maintaining millisecond-low latencies
  - Optimized to handle extreme and unstable traffic patterns    

- **Classic Load balancers**
    - Distribute incoming network traffic across multiple EC2 instances in as many AZs as you require for performance

question.prompt: What AWS Load Balancer service would you use to route web traffic based on how your code is performing?
Which of the following is true for Network Load Balancers?

answers.text: Load balances TCP and UDP traffic
Can route traffic based on IP data
Uses DNS Round Robin to route traffic

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Reading    

Learn more about Routing  

- [Choosing a Routing Policy](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/routing-policy.html)  
- [Optimizing Network Performance- VIDEO](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DWiwuYtIgu0)  
- [Network Performance in AWS- 5 Factors](https://www.networkcomputing.com/networking/network-performance-aws-5-factors)  
- [AWS Route 53](https://aws.amazon.com/route53/)  
- [AWS Route 53 FAQs](https://aws.amazon.com/route53/faqs/)  
- [AWS Transit Gateway](https://aws.amazon.com/transit-gateway/)  
- [AWS Global Accelerator](https://aws.amazon.com/global-accelerator/)  
- [AWS Transit Gateway Network Manager](https://aws.amazon.com/transit-gateway/network-manager/)

atoms.title: Network Diagram
atoms.text:
### Creating an Architectural Diagram

Please feel free to create your schematic with your preferred diagramming application. I used LucidChart to create the diagrams for this course. 

LucidChart has a free version that allows you to save some files without the monthly service charge. The free version should be sufficient for the exercises in this course. 

[LucidChart](https://www.lucidchart.com)  

When you create a new blank document, make sure you find and select the AWS 2017 or AWS 2019 shapes by clicking on the gear icon in the upper left corner of the ‘Shapes’ menu and searching for AWS. The AWS shapes will help you create your diagram with accurate shapes and icons.

atoms.title: Network Diagram
tasks: Using the diagramming application of your choice, start with a blank diagram
Create a diagram with a minimum of the following elements: A Cloud Provider, A VPC, Public and Private Subnets, An EC2 instance, a database, and an external client
Use arrows to show how the elements are connected or networked
atoms.positive_feedback: Great Job! You can see my diagram in the next video
atoms.description: Please follow the prompts below to create an AWS network diagram

atoms.title: ND063 C2 L2 17 My Soluton - Diagram
Solution Recap
atoms.text:
### Key Points 

- Cloud architects, system administrators, and operations engineers spend a portion of their work time on technical writing and documentation. 

- Architecture diagrams are a way of communicating abstract technical concepts in a concrete and visual way

- Architecture and Network diagrams are knowledge sharing tools that document technical configuration for planning, guidance, and corporate history.

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Reading  

Continue learning about architecture and network diagrams by following the links provided below.
- [AWS Reference Architecture and Diagrams](https://aws.amazon.com/whitepapers/?whitepapers-main.sort-by=item.additionalFields.sortDate&whitepapers-main.sort-order=desc&awsf.whitepapers-content-type=content-type%23arch-diagram)  
- [How to Create Architecture Diagrams](https://sysadmincasts.com/episodes/62-how-to-create-architecture-diagrams)  
- [The Art of Crafting Architectural DIagrams](https://www.infoq.com/articles/crafting-architectural-diagrams/)  
- [What is a network Diagram?](https://www.lucidchart.com/pages/network-diagram)  
- [17 Tips to Better Network Diagrams](http://networkdiagram101.com/)

atoms.title: recap heading
atoms.text: ## Performance in the Cloud Recap

atoms.title: Lesson Recap
atoms.text:
Maintaining high performing cloud infrastructure requires training, time, and data.Cloud providers are always making performance improvements to their services and offering incentives to make periodic upgrades attractive to their customers.

In order to achieve optimal performance, you need the data to support your service and configuration choices. Taking the time to monitor your cloud workloads will reward you with  performance optimized systems.

atoms.title: Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Reading on Performance   
Learn more here: 

- [The AWS Reliability Pillar- Performance](https://wa.aws.amazon.com/wat.pillar.performance.en.html)  
- [Approaching Cloud Computing Performance](https://www.computer.org/csdl/magazine/cd/2018/02/mcd2018020033/13rRUwkfB1z)  
- [Why Cloud Apps Don’t Perform and What You Can Do About it](https://techbeacon.com/app-dev-testing/why-cloud-apps-dont-perform-what-you-can-do-about-it)

atoms.title: New Terms in this Lesson
atoms.text:
| Term | Definition |
|:----------------------|:----| 
| Auto Scaling Group              | AWS EC2 instances that are treated as a logical grouping for the purposes of automatic scaling and management  |      | 
| Availability       | A storage volume’s ability to deliver data upon request| 
| AWS Direct Connect              | A cloud service solution that makes it easy to establish a dedicated network connection from your premises to AWS   | 
| AWS DynamoDB                    | A key-value and document database that delivers single-digit millisecond performance at any scale. It's a fully managed, multiregion, multimaster, durable database with built-in security, backup and restore, and in-memory caching for internet-scale applications  | 
| AWS Global Accelerator          | Service that improves the availability and performance of your applications with local or global users. It provides static IP addresses that act as a fixed entry point to your application endpoints        | 
| AWS RDS| A web service that makes it easier to set up, operate, and scale a relational database in the cloud                 | 
| AWS VPC Endpoints   | Used to privately connect your VPC to other AWS services and endpoint services             | 
| Burstable Performance Instances | T3, T3a, and T2 instances, are designed to provide a baseline level of CPU performance with the ability to burst to a higher level when required by your workload       | 
| CloudFront                      | Uses a global network of 216 Points of Presence To deliver content to end users with lower latency                  | 
| Consumer                        | Receives messages to an SQS queue| 
| Content Delivery Network        | A series of distributed servers that deliver content to users based on location            | 
| Data Durability                 | Refers to long-term data protection, so the stored data does not suffer from degradation or some other corruption. Durability is focused on redundancy, , sodata is never lost or compromised       | 
| Decoupling                      | Refers to components remaining autonomous and unaware of each other as they complete their work for some greater output                   | 
| Edge Cache                      | Servers used to store content closer to end users           | 
| Edge Location                   | Where end users access services provided by AWS             | 
| Elastic Block Store             | High performance block storage service designed for use with Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) for both throughput and transaction intensive workloads                 | 
| Elastic File System             | Fully managed elastic NFS file system for use with AWS Cloud services and on-premises resources. It is built to scale on demand to petabytes without disrupting applications, growing and shrinking automatically     | 
| Elasticity                      | The ability to grow or shrink infrastructure resources dynamically as needed to automatically adapt to workload changes, maximizing the use of resources and resulting in savings in infrastructure costs    | 
| Expedited Retrieval             | Faster access to your data when you need to have almost immediate access to your information within 1-5 minutes. This retrieval type can be used for archives up to 250MB.          | 
| FIFO   | Queues designed to ensure that the order in which messages are sent and received is strictly preserved and that each message is processed exactly once- First In, First Out         | 
| GPU (Graphics Processing Unit)  | A programmable chip used to manage and boost the performance of video and graphics. GPU renders images, animations, and video for the computer's screen | 
| Instance Family   | Six distinct classifications of EC2 instance optimized for different types of applications | 
| IOPS   | Input/output operations per second (IOPS, pronounced eye-ops) is an input/output performance measurement used to benchmark computer storage devices like hard disk drives (HDD), solid state drives (SSD)    | 
| Latency| Generally refers to a transport or transfer delay           | 
| Latency Routing                 | Configuration where DNS requests are routed from the AWS region that provides the lowest latency                    | 
| Launch Configuration            | an instance configuration template that an Auto Scaling group uses to launch EC2 instances |  
| Lift and  Shift  | The process of moving your application from an on-premises environment to the cloud without making any major changes to the code  | 
| Non-Relational Database         | A database that does not use the tabular schema of rows and columns found in most traditional database systems. Instead, non-relational databases use a storage model that is optimized for the specific requirements of the type of data being stored| 
| Optimized Instances             | Instance types optimized to fit different use cases. Instance types comprise varying combinations of CPU, memory, storage, GPU, and networking capacity and give you the flexibility to choose the appropriate mix of resources for your applications | 
| Performance                     | Refers to the number of IOPS or the amount of throughput (measured in megabytes per second) that the storage volume can deliver           | 
| Placement Groups  | Influence the placement of a group of interdependent instances to meet the needs of your workload |               | 
| Points of Presence   | Made up of Edge locations and regional edge caches          | 
| Predictive Scaling   | A feature of AWS Auto Scaling uses machine learning to schedule the right number of EC2 instances in anticipation of approaching traffic changes. Predictive Scaling predicts future traffic, including regularly-occurring spikes, and provisions the right number of EC2 instances in advance | 
| Producer                        | Sends messages to an SQS queue   | 
| Provisioned Capacity            | Paying up front to ensure that S3 expedited retrieval capacity is available when you need it                        | 
| Read Replica                    | A copy of the master db that reflects changes to the master instance in almost real time |        
| Relational Database             | A set of formally described tables from which data can be accessed or reassembled in many different ways without having to reorganize the database tables               | 
| Retrieval Job      | An asynchronous operation in which you first initiate a job, and then download the output after the job completes   | 
| Route 53     | A highly available and scalable cloud Domain Name System (DNS) web service| 
| S3 Glacier      | Storage service optimized for infrequently used, or "cold data." Glacier is a low-cost storage service that provides durable storage with security features for data archiving and backup           | 
| S3 IA  | S3 storage class for data that is accessed less frequently, but requires rapid access when needed.                  | 
| SQS    | A fully managed message queuing service that enables you to decouple and scale microservices, distributed systems, and serverless application  | 
| Target Utilization              | The threshold we define at how much utilization (in %) we want auto scaling to take place |  
| Throughput                      | Measurement of data that can be transferred from one location to another in a given amount of time used to measure the performance of hard drives and RAM as well as Internet and network connections        | 
| Transient or Ephemeral Data     | Data created within an application session, and at the end of the session, it is discarded or reset back to its default and not stored    | 
| VPC    | A logically isolated section of the AWS Cloud where you can launch AWS resources in a virtual network you define    | 
| Workload                        | A collection of resources and code that delivers business value, such as a customer-facing application or a backend process               |
